title: Himerios (admiral)
text:
Himerios (<a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a>: ), also Himerius, was a <a href="Byzantine">Byzantine</a> administrator and admiral of the early 10th century, best known as the commander of the <a href="Byzantine%20navy">Byzantine navy</a> during its struggles with the resurgent <a href="Islam">Muslim</a> navies in the period 900–912.
Biography.
Nothing is known about Himerios's early life. He was married to the sister of <a href="Zoe%20Karbonopsina">Zoe Karbonopsina</a>, the mistress and later wife of Emperor <a href="Leo%20VI%20the%20Wise">Leo VI the Wise</a> (r. 886–912), and his career was the direct result of this relationship.
Initially a "<a href="Protasekretis">protasēkrētis</a>", Himerios was appointed in command of the Byzantine fleet in 904. A Muslim fleet under <a href="Leo%20of%20Tripoli">Leo of Tripoli</a> was heading towards <a href="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> and had already driven back the Byzantines under the "<a href="droungarios%20tou%20ploimou">droungarios tou ploimou</a>" <a href="Eustathios%20Argyros%20%28admiral%20under%20Leo%20VI%29">Eustathios Argyros</a>. Eustathios was replaced by Himerios, who, however, did not have to fight, as the <a href="Arabs">Arabs</a> withdrew on their own. The two fleets encountered each other off <a href="Thasos">Thasos</a>, but the Byzantines chose not to give battle. As a result, the Arabs were able to <a href="Sack%20of%20Thessalonica%20%28904%29">besiege and sack</a> <a href="Thessalonica">Thessalonica</a>, the Byzantine Empire's second-largest city, and sail home unopposed.
On <a href="Thomas%20the%20Apostle">St. Thomas</a>'s day (6 October) in 906, Himerios managed to score his first victory over the Arabs, and it was probably then that he was awarded the high state office of "<a href="logothetes%20tou%20dromou">logothetēs tou dromou</a>" (effectively foreign minister). Another victory followed in 909, and in the next year, he led an expedition on the <a href="Bilad%20al-Sham">Syrian</a> coast: <a href="Latakia">Laodicea</a> was sacked, its hinterland plundered, and many prisoners captured, with minimal losses. At the same time, Himerios also landed on <a href="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, which for centuries had been demilitarized as a <a href="Condominium%20%28international%20law%29">condominium</a> with the <a href="Caliphate">Caliphate</a>. The recovery of the island was temporary only, as in 911 or 912, <a href="Damian%20of%20Tarsus">Damian of Tarsus</a> assaulted Cyprus. Eventually, the previous "status quo" was restored.
In meantime, in the autumn of 911, Himerios had set out on a new attempt to retake <a href="Emirate%20of%20Crete">Crete</a>. He commanded a fleet of 177 <a href="dromon">dromon</a>s with 43,000 men, and set the island's capital, <a href="Iraklio">Chandax</a>, under siege. The siege had lasted for six months, when news arrived from Constantinople that the emperor was ill and dying. Consequently, Himerios abandoned the fruitless siege and set sail for the capital. However, as his fleet was rounding <a href="Chios">Chios</a>, they fell into a Saracen ambush set by Leo of Tripoli and Damian of Tarsus (April 912): the Byzantines were annihilated, and Himerios himself only narrowly escaped. Following this defeat and the death of Emperor Leo, he was dismissed by the new emperor, <a href="Alexander%20%28Byzantine%20emperor%29">Alexander</a> (r. 912–913), and exiled to the <a href="monastery">monastery</a> of Kamba, where he died six months later.
